awd_abstract_narration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad. 

This award will support a twenty-four month research fellowship by Dr. Licia C. Ray to work with Dr. Nicholas Achilleos at University College London in London, United Kingdom.  

Magnetic braking, the process by which a star sheds angular momentum to its surrounding plasma and spins down, is an important process in solar system formation. Jupiter's interaction with its surrounding plasma disc is a local analog for this interaction. Thus far, magnetosphere-ionosphere (M-I) coupling models of angular momentum transport have not been able to reconcile in situ measurements of Jupiter's magnetospheric plasma (radial mass transport rates and angular velocity profiles) with observations of Jupiter's auroral emission - a bright signature of this coupling. However, previous models simplified the treatment of either the ionosphere or the magnetosphere, inadequately coupling the thermospheric and magnetospheric flows by neglecting the differential rotation allowed by field-aligned potentials.

This research merges the University of Colorado magnetospheric model of angular momentum transfer with the University College London Jovian Ionosphere Model, building the first comprehensive system model of Jupiter's M-I coupling which treats the atmosphere and magnetosphere with equal sophistication and investigates how field-aligned potentials affect the atmospheric properties of the parent bodies and thus the net transport of angular momentum. By varying the planetary mass, magnetic field strength, and rotation rate this research will also quantify magnetic braking for early stars with applications to extra-solar system formation.

This work will develop new international collaborations between the PI and the research group at University College London.  It will contribute to the understanding of the coupled magnetosphere-ionosphere-thermosphere system of Jupiter and of early stars, which has inter-disciplinary applications to the fields of aeronomy, magnetospheric physics, and solar system formation.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated the interaction between Jupiter's upper atmosphere and its surrounding magnetosphere. Jupiter's magnetosphere is the largest object in the solar system and is populated with a large population of plasma - ionized gas - ultimately originating from material outgassed by the volcanic moon, Io. Iogenic plasma is connected to Jupiter's atmosphere through Jupiter's magnetic field and electrical currents that run through the atmosphere, along the magnetic field, and then radially outwards in the equatorial plane of the magnetosphere. Stresses from the motion of Iogenic plasma outward through the magnetosphere are communicated to the planetary atmosphere via the magnetic field and electrical currents, and can affect the winds and temperature of the atmosphere. A visible signature of this interaction is the bright planetary aurora observed by telescopes, including Hubble and Keck. Understanding what influences the communication and transfer of energy and momentum between the atmosphere and magnetosphere is important because the same process may exist around young stars and early extra solar-systems, offering insight into how our solar system formed.

Our approach was to couple a numerical General Circulation Model of Jupiter's upper atmosphere to a model of the electrical currents and fields which couple the atmosphere to the magnetosphere. For the first time, we included the development of field-aligned voltages at high magnetic latitudes. Auroral observations indicated that these voltages can reach 100s of kilovolts. Their effect is to increase the electrical current, and hence communication, between the atmosphere and magnetosphere. If the strength of the voltage varies with planetary latitude, then they also allow the atmosphere and magnetosphere to rotate independently. Depending on the location where these voltages develop, they can also act to cap the electrical currents running between the two regions.

We found that when these voltages are included in a detailed numerical treatment of the magnetosphere-atmosphere system, the reduce the strength of the winds that develop in the planetary atmosphere to stresses in the magnetosphere. This is an important result because energy deposited in the atmosphere from the electrical currents can now be transported both towards the equator and pole, helping to explain the 700 K (1260 F) degree temperature excess observed in Jupiter's atmosphere. 

Another result of our work was to show that we need to further advance our modeling efforts of giant planet systems. Jupiter's magnetosphere varies depending on local time (for example, when looking out from the planet at midnight, the magnetosphere has a different structure than when looking out at dawn). Models of either the magnetosphere or the atmosphere have included variations with local time for years. However, because of the computational complexity in describing the communication between the atmosphere and magnetosphere, the assumption that the system is symmetric (dawn and midnight are 'close enough') has always been applied when trying to describe both regions at once. We used a description of Jupiter's magnetic field from spacecraft observations, which varied in local time to show that the symmetric assumption incorrectly predicts the behaviour of the surroundings. Future work will challange this assumption, in order to better aide data analysis from telescope observations and spacecraft measurements.

The results from both studies above have been submitted for publication in two international science journals. Our work was also presented at international meetings and workshops, in Europe, the US, and Japan.
